cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Ormus" will leave Suez about April 5
R.M.S "Oruba" will leave Suez about April 19.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Orotava" will leave Port Said April 9
R.M.S. “Ophir" will leave Port Said April 22

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season 15th May - 15th September.
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.
For all imformation apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-6

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON.
S.S. Staffordshire 6,005 tons, will leave Suez about April 11th.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Cheshire 5,775 tons, will leave Port Said about April 14th.
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0 ; London £17.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangood £37.10.0
Fitted with Refigerators, Electric Light, Electric Fans and all recent improvements.
SPECIAL REDUCED FARES DURING THE SUMMER SEASON. 12-931
Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.p: DE PARIS.
CAPITAL: 150,000,000 frs,-£ 6,000,000 FULLY PAID UP. — HEAD OFFICE: 14, Rue Bergere, Paris
Alexandria Branch 11, Rue Cherif Pacha.—40 Branches in Paris, and 112 Throughout France.

Branches in London, Liverpool, Manchester, Morocco, Tunis, East India, Madagascar, Australia, etc. Bills Collected. Deposit Accounts opened at sight & for fixed periods, Advances on securities, in current account. Letters of Credit and Telegraphic Transfers Issued. Foreign Exhange Bought and Sold. Stocks and Valuables received in safe custody. Purchase and Sale of Stock & Shares in Egypt and Abroad. Dividends Collected.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: CAPITAL FRANCS 250,000,000 ENTIEREMENT VERSES
Agences d’Egypte : ALEXANDRIE, LE CAIRE, PORT-SAID.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l’étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d’effets sur l’Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d’Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d’un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d’un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 2833781-3-906

The Banque du Caire Ltd., undertakes all banking business such as : Advances on deeds and securites, discount, cheques delivered at very best rates of exchange on all the principal towns of the world, telegraphic transfers, purchase and sale of stock and shares in Egypt and abroad, letters of credit issued, safe custoday at a low charge, of titles, deeds and securities, current accounts opened. THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

p.hi: Public Analyst for the City of Glasgow and the Counties of Lanark, Renfrew, &c.

div.p: N.B.—This Whisky is the same as supplied to the Red Cross Society, London, to the House of Lords and House of Commons.
N. SPATHIS, Agent.
CAIRO and ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: P & O WEEKLY MAIL and PASSENGER SERVICES P & O
div.p: EGYPT to BRINDISI, MARSEILLES & LONDON.
(Special connecting Train Services between Brindisi and London, and between Marseilles and London.)
PORT SAID to LONDON via MARSEILLES 5 1/2 Days
PORT SAID to LONDON by SEA 12 Days
REDUCED SUMMER FARES
PORT SAID to LONDON via BRINDISI in 4 1/2Days
Passengers can embark on Monday evening in the Brindisi steamer, which is timed to leave Port Said on Tuesday morning immediately after arrival of the homeward Indian Mail.
The Marseilles London Steamers sail after the arrival of the 11 a.m train from Cairo on Tuesdays.
25 per Cent. Abatement off Homeward Sea Fare to passengers making return Journey within 12 months.
Particulars of additional departures by Intermediate Steamers at reduced fares, to Malta, Calcutta, Straits, China, Japan, and London, may be had on application.

THOS. COOK A SON (EGYPT), LTD. ... CAIRO.
G. ROYLE .. ... PORT SAID,
HASELDEN & Co. ... .. ... ...ALEXANDRIA.
or from the Company's superintendent in Egypt,
F. G. DAVIDSON, Suez.

div.head: Consulat Imp. d'Allemagne a Alexandrie. Vente aux encheres publiques de divers meubles.
div.p: Le vendredi 28 Juin 1907, à 9i heures du matin il sera procédé A la vente aux enchères publiques, par l'huissier du tribunal consulaire d'Allemagne, des objets suivants :
1 buffet, 1 servante, 1 armoire, 1 table à manger, 6 chaises, 1 lampe, 1 secrétaire américain.
Cette vente sera faite en vertu d'un titre exécutoire du tribunal consulaire allemand et aura lieu A Kafr-el-Zayat.
Paiement comptant en or, réception inné diate, 5% droit de criee. Pour information veuillez vous adresser au Consulat d’Allemagne.
L’Huissier
Du Tribunal Consulaire d’Allemagne Range.
Alexandrie, le 21 Juin 1907. 30540-1

div.head: The United Egyptian Lands, Limited
div.p: NOTICE TO SHAREHOLDERS.
In accordance with a resolution taken by
the Board of Directors of this Company’ to
make the Final Call of 5/- per Share on the —
Ordinary Shares, I hereby beg to-notify Share-
holders, that said Final: Call of 5/- per Share
becomes payable on 28th December 1907 at
the National Bank of Egypt Alexandria and
Cairo.
Call Notices will be duly issued.to Share i
holders who must pay the amounts due by
them to the Bank on the above mentioned date.
L. Des Clayes.
Secretary in Egypt.

Agencies wanted where not already represented. Write, giving references, to Magna Cider Co., Maraton Magna, Somerset, England. 28303-4*-3

div.head: BERLITZ SCHOOLS OF LANGUAGES
div.p: 236 BRANCHES.
French, German, Italian, Greek, Arabic, etc.
Private Lessons, Residence Lessons, taught by Native Masters
ALEXANDRIA: 26 Rue Rosette (close to Zizinia Theatre.)
CAIRO : 1 Sharia Kamel.
TRIAL LESSONS FREE

div.head: A Tunieian Vieltor.
div.p: Said Sidi Safaar, Director of the Tunisian
Wakfs, is on a visit-to Egypt and is staying
with the Princess Nazli Hanem.

div.head: Nile Navigation.
div.p: Owing to repairs to the railway bridge over
the Rayah Tawfiki, at Benha, navigation is
interrupted at this site till further notice.

div.head: Chezireh Palace Hotél.
div.p: The Ghezireh Palace Hotel: reopens for the
season to-day. Many orders are already book-
ed for appartments.

div.head: The Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: The Lirica Lillipatian. troupe scored another | and Japan were excellent and that it was quite] bring civil sation, Ayainattrysoffete of his
great success last night at the Alhambra
theatre in “Cavalleria Rusticana,” which is to
be repeated to-night.

div.head: The Cotton Plant.
div.p: Mr. F. Fletcher, Principal of the Khedivial
College of Agriculture, Ghizeh, has contributed
a long article on the cotton .plant to the
“Manchester Guardian” of November 27th.

div.head: Prisons Administration.
div.p: Messrs. Thos. Cook and Son, Ltd., have
obtained the contract for the supply and in-
stallation of the necessary machines at the new | Pathans,
reformatory at Gizeh at a cost of L.E. 5,320.

div.head: The Mational Bank. .
div.p: Mr. Sidney Bray, sub-manager of the Na-
tional Bank, Khartoum, has resigned his posi-
tion, and has been appointed agent of the
Minieh branch of the National Bank in Egypt.
Mr. Bray and Mrs. Bray left. Khartoum last
week via the Port Sudan route last week,

div.head: Kamel Pasha’'s Health.
div.p: We regret to hear that the health of
Mustapha Pasha Kamel at the present mouggnt
leaves a great deal to be desired, and it is not
improbable that his physical condition may
prevent him from taking an active participation
in political life.

div.head: Shepheards Hotel.
div.p: The next small dance will be given at
Shepheards on Saturday and afterwards small
dances will be held every Tuesday, The
Christmas free entertainment is to be held at
Shepheard’s on Tuesday 24th inst. at 5 p.m.
and the “Grand Ball” will. be given on Tuesday
28th January. The Fancy Dress Ball at the
Casino, Ghezireh, will be given on Shrove
Tuesday.

div.head: Engtish Companies in Egypt.
div.p: A Cairo aren. yond published a telegram
from London, dated the 7th inst., to the effect
that the Foreign Office was on the point of
asking Sir Eldon Gorst to study the situation
of liability companies in Egypt register-
ed under the companies Acts. We are in a
position to state that the British Agency is
quite unaware of any snch intention on the
part of the Foreign Office.

div.head: Purification of Exyptian Railways.
div.p: The Egyptian Government Railways has ac-
cepted the tender of the Clayton Gas Company
of Egypt and the Sudan for the purification of
their rolling stock by means of this well-known
process. Suitable gaslight sheds are now being
erected at Cairo for the systematic disinfection
of the railway carriages. This important new
process will afford a great security to the
travelling public. Moreover it will be a consider: |
able saving of expense to the Egyptian Rail-
way Administration as it will prevent the des-
tructjon of their fittings by moth and dust.

div.head: “The Sphinx”.
div.p: We welcome the first number of the fifteenth
yolume of our ever popular ‘Cairo weekly
season contemporary the “Sphinx”, which ap-
pears in better form than’ ever Under the
editorship and managership of Mr. H. W.
Hewlett there is no doubt but that this journal
will continue in its path of steady progress and
enhance the popularity which it has gained.
Fis contents are diverse—social, sporting, wit
and humour, fashions for ladies, »military |
notes, billiard notes, motor-car fotes, short
stories by well-known authors, finapcial sotes
from London, local impressions, lists of those
staying at the hotels of Lower and Upper
Egypt and the Sudan, information for visitors
to the. country, ete ete: The illustrations
which the joufnal contains are md%t excellent
and will be thoroughly appreciated by its
readers, the nambers of whom increase year by
year. Prominént among those of the nuffber
under review are photographs of Sir Eldon and
Lady Gorst, Major General Bullock, C. B.,
and his staff, the funeral procession of the late
Princess Hanern, King Edward's Birthday ye
view, and some excellent views of Phile.
We learn by Marconigram that the “He
liopolis” will arrive at 5 p.m.

div.head: AN EXTRAORDINARY RUMOUR.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Monday.
An extraordinary rumour is published by
the “Echode Paris” in a telegram from Toulon
which states that great activity is being
regard
to the situation between America and Japan.
On the other hand, Mr. Taft, speaking at
Berlin, said that the relations between America
and Japan were excellent and that it was quite
erroneos to suppose that America had any
intention of disturbing the peace.

div.head: THE ZULULAND SITUATION.
div.p: ( Gazette's Special Service. )
London, Monday,
Affairs in Zuloland are said to be improving.
Many. Transvaal Indiana, including Sikhs,
Pathans, and Goorkhas, sre offering their
services to their authorities.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK
div.p: NEW DIRECTOR APPOINTED.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
Lendon, Monday.
Mr. Hector Foa, of the firm Messrs. King
and Foa, has been appointed Director of the
Anglo-Egyptian Bank. His father was for many
years secretary and manager of the bank.

div.head: LOAN FOR MOROCCO.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Monday,
The Sultan of Morocco has effected a loan
of £6,000,000, granting France a control of the
country’s finance.
SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.
Jodgemeut was given yesterday evening in
the case of Montano v. the Anglo-Egyptian
Bank Limited, The Court rose at 6 p.m and
judgment was given at 6.45 p.m. after the jury
had deliberated for three quarters of an hour.
The Court found for the plaintiff ons amount
£1706 0s. 6d. and costs. The Anglo-Egyptian
Bank had admitted liability with the defence
and had paid £200 as sufficient damages to
meet the ease. The jury was composed of
Messrs. Perey W. Carver, Frank Hasleden,
Captain Samuel Fawcett, Henry Thomas and
Henry Hanley. Owing to the length of time
this case has taken these gentlemen have
been excused from sérving on a jury’ for
three years.
The Supreme Consular Court did not sit
to-day. The following cases.are dowh for hearing
in the undermentioned dates : Wednesday,
11th inst., Bourse and Banking Company of
Egypt, Appeal Cases ; 11th and 12th Carasso
y. Carasso, 13th inst , Estate of Balzan, applic-
ation by Dr Rizzo-at 11.30 am. 14th inst.
Barker's Estate. 16th inst. Canton murder
case.

div.head: THE INTERNATIONAL CRECHE.
div.p: The Intertational Créche which was opened
in Alexandria on June 17th, has fully shown
that it serves a much felt want among the
pooer classes of the population, for from that
date until the 30th ulto, there was a total of
2110 attendances by 120. different children.
These include 46 Syrian, 36 Greeks, 17 Italian,
14 Arabs, 4 Maltese, and 3 Cop's The average
attendance is about 23 daily. This is the only
institution. of the kind in Alexandria where
childrenare taken by the day. The créche
at the Maternity Home takes babies entirely
ander its charge and the Greek community
has a créche for foundlings, bat the interna
tional eréche is specially for children, whose
mother sare At work during the day. Of the
mothérs of the childreen regularly attending
this institation 6 are washerwomen, <7 dress-
makers, 2 or 3 in domestic service, 2 hat-
makers, while the others take in sewing at
home. The children have three meals a day,
inéluding an excellent midday meal and are
bathed every morning. In October the num-
bers of children in attendance during the
whole month totalled 562, which was the larg-
est number that has been attained. Since then
the bad weather las diminished the attendan-
ce! but even now it barely falls below 20° The
present Aéad-quarters of the oréche are at El
Fabrizi street, near the Bab el-Ghedid Termin-
lus. It is intended to remove it to another
house in the Bab Sidra quarter, which will be
more convenient for the parents being nest
the indostrial. part of the city and will have
the advantage of a garden. The health of the
children hes been generally excellent
institution will not be allowed to suffer through
lack of funds. Contributions, however small,
will also be welcome and any stall offering
will be gratefully accepted, all cash donations
sent to the Secretary, Ismall Sedley
Bey, at the Alexandria Municipality.

div.head: PRINCESS BONAPARTE IN
GREECE.
div.p: Athens, December 9.
Princess Bonapatte has disembarked at
Piraeus. The King and the Royal Family went
to meet her. The Mayors of Pirseus and Athéns
read addresses and the people warmly welcom
ed her. (Havas)

div.head: THE FRENCH BUDGET.
div.p: Parts, December 9.
The Chamber of Deputies sitting on Sunday
adopted the budget: The Socialist, M. Car-
nand, brought in an amendment raising the
tax on speculative bourse transactions,in spite
of the opposition of the Minister of Finance,
who while agreeing to the principle, opposed
the increase at the present time of monetary
crisis as tending to cause a panic on the Paris
market. ( Reuter)

div.head: SURRENDER OF DINI ZULU.
div.p: Pietermaritzburg, December 9.
There is an unconfirmed report that Dini
Zulu surrendered yesterday.
(Later). The surrender of Dini Zulu is con-
firmed. A conveyance has been sent to fetch
him. (Reuter)
STRIKE OF GOLD MINERS
San Francisco, December 9
A serious situation has arisen in the gold
fields district of Nevada owing to an extensive
strike, the miners objecting to payment by
cheques
The strikers destroyed the railway by dyna
mite for the purpose of blowing up the troops
sent from here.
A catastrophe was only averted by the vigi-
lance of a special gang of trackwalkers.( Reuter )

div.head: A CALIFORNIA TRUST
COMPANY.
div.p: THREE DIRECTORS ARRESTED.
San Francisco, December 9.
Three directors of the California Safe De-
posit Trost Company have been arrested on the
charge of misappropriation of fund. It is ae-
certained that the Company’s liabilities afiount
to 9,000,000 dollars and its assets to 4,000,000
dollars. (Reuter)

div.head: KING OF SWEDEN.
div.p: Stockholm, December 9.
The King will take the title of Gustav V.
The funeral of the late King will take place in a
fortnight. ( Reuter)

div.head: THE KAISER IN ENGLAND.
div.p: London, December 9.
The German Emperor has terminated his
visit to High Cliffe and retarned here. He is
in excellent health, He lunched with King
Edward and King Haakon at Buckingham.
(Reuter )

div.head: ASSINIA AND TURKEY.
div.p: (THROUGH REUTER'S AGENCY).
Constantinople, December 3.
The special Abyssinian mission, under the
presidency of General Dedjaz Mechecha, has
returned to Constantinople. The Mission was
received last Friday after the Selamlik ceremony
in private audience by the Sultan. In the
course of the andience General Mechecha
remitted to his Majesty a letter signed by
Negua Menelik in which the Emperor thanks
the Sultan for the welcome given to the mission
on its last visit to Constantinople and
expresses the hope that a friendly solution will
be arrived at concerning the possession by the
Abyssinians of the convent at Jerusalem known
as Deir Sultan, at present held by the Copts-
Until now the Mission bas only been able: to
obtain a half support, by the division of the
keys between the two parties. General Mechecha
hopes to obtain the. exclusive rights. In ten days
he will leave for Abyssinia via Jerusalem.

div.head: MAIDEN VOYAGE OF THE "HELIOPOLIS"
div.p: (From Our Special Correspondent. )
London, December 2.
The magnificent steamer "Heliopolis,” of
the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company, com-
menced her first voyage on November 28,
when she left her moorings at Greenock to
proceed to Plymouth, en route for Marseilles.
The strong westerly yale of the previous day
had moderated, and the ship started on her
tripdown the Firth of Clyde under the most
favourable auspices. In addition to the pas-
sengers for Egypt who had selected to set
out from Scotland, there was a goodly number
of experts in maritime matters, who proceeded
as far as Plymouth, in order to personally
test and experience the sea-going qualities of
the ship. Among the large company on board
were the Chairman, Lord Armstrong, and Mr.
Q. T. Symons, Managing Director of the
Egyptian Mail Steamship Company ; Mr. A. 8.
Williams, manager of the Royal Mail Steam-
ship Company; Mr. J.8. Inglis, general ma-
‘nagerof theGreat Western Railway and others.
The. “Heliopolis” and her sister ship, the
“Cairo,” are both built by the Fairfield Shipbuild-
ing Company, of Glasgow, and are not only tur-
bine driven but propelled by triple screws,
all working by turbine: mechanism, the gpgine
horse-power being 18,000 and the ship’s ton-
nage 12,000 gross. The most noticeable feature
with regard to this use of the turbine system
is the absence of vibration and the noise ine-
vitably associated more or less with the. old
reciprocating-engine arrangements, and in this,
as in every other respect, the vessel must be
pronounces a complete success. Although dur
ing aportion ofthe voyage a speed wasobtained
of 22 knots, in most parts of the ship the
fact of her being in rapid motion was hardly
perceptible, and, indeed, the mental effect was
so slight that the passengers wondered whether
the vessel had not temporarily ceased “going
ahead.”
Some particulars of the magnificent equip-
ment of the “Heliopolis” -were published by us
on the occasion of the launch, but now that all
the interior arrangements and the elaborate
decorations are complete, for which Mr. F. W
Collinson is responsiblé, a far better idea of
her splendour and comfort can be obtained.
The idea which has been so successfully achiev-
‘ed, was to construct a vessel in which every-
thing should be sithordinated to the require-
menta of passengers. Ibe considerations, there
fore, as to the conveyance of cargo have been
kept in the back-ground.
Some idea of the dimensions of the “Helio-
polis” may be formed when it is explained that
there are in all seven decks, apon five of which,
at léast, large state-rooms and numerous ele-
gant saloons are arranged. Abaft the officers’
quarters upon the upper deck is a café design-
ed in Regency style in panelled oak. Below
this, upon what is termed the promenade deck,
is the Jarge deck-house, and in this, as also on
the deck below, are a series of magnificent
saloons, only equalled by the reception rooms
of a first-class modern hotel.
The saloon upon the promenade deck is
arranged as a ‘insic room, and is 45 feet by
30, most charmingly furnished in Louis Quinze
style, finighed in white. Upon the bridge deck
are the library decorated in Regence style, and
the smoking room, 50 feet, by 40 exeellently
ventilated. Upon the stage below is the magnifi-
cent dining saloon, capable of seating some
260 persons at one time. Jt is fitted with tables
of various sizes, to accomodate both large and
small parties of travellers. From personal
experience during the voyage, we can unlftsita-
tingly assert that the cuisine could not be
surpassed. The food is of the finest quality, and
the chefs employed are masters of the culinary
art. As there are so. many stages and decks, a lift
has been provided for the convenience of passen-
gers, and everything that can conduce to their
comfort in the way of electric lighting, ventil-
ating fans, eté. even including electric curling
tongs, in the cabins have been provided. Great
eare must have been exercised, arid advice of
responsible experts obtained, in the selection
of the library, for not only have the choicest
works of modern fiction a:.d travel been chosen,
but others of a more erudite character upon
Egyptological subjects, besides such booka‘of
history as may be suid to; possess an interna-
tivnal reputation, are yenerously provided. We
cordially wish the Egyptian Mail. Steamship
Company the success to which their enterprise
entitles them, especially when it is realised
that they are offering the public a service that
is unique in more ways than one. Not only do

div.head: LORD CROMER'S SPEECH
div.p: "Fiscal" writes to "The Times" saying:-
You reported Lord Cromer as having stated that
“during the whole ‘course of the occupation the
principles of free trade have been rigidly ap-
plied in Egypt.”
May I ask him to explain how it is that in
the Estimstes for 1907 £1,800,000 figures as
revenue from customs—this sum being over
12 per cent. of the entire estimated revenue
and nearly 4 per cent. on the entire imports and
exports of merchandise
Is it not afact that there is a 1 percent.
ad talorem duty on all exports from Egypt
and a 4 per cent. ad valorem daty on all im-
ports into Egypt.
I am, of course, familiar with the possible
answer that these duties are levied for revenue
and not for protective, purposes; but I would
snggest that, while no one would advocate
even a 4 per cent. ad valorem daty on all im-
ports into the United Kingdom, such a pro-
posal might be defended on exactly the same
grounds and would, I am sure, be, notwith-
standing, vigorously denounced as rank protec-
tion by all the gentlemen with whom Lord
Cromer associates himself.
Out of the 24 millions imports into Egypt
I find that over three millions are “cereals and
vegetables.” It would be interesting to know
whether this duty on food is 4 per cent. or 8
Tobacco figures as an import for nearly,
£700,000. Has not the growing of tobacco
been prohibited in Egypt, and is this a rigid
application of free-trade principles

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p: Family Hotel. Built in 1904. Between Shepheard's Hotel and the Railway Station. Electric Light. Lift.
Sanitary arrangements up to-date. Open all the year round. Special terms for Government officials and Army of Occupation

div.p: The first race meeting of the Helouan Sport: | oe :

div.head: Notice to Advertisers.
div.p: The “Egyptian Gazette” has given
no advertising agency or company
in Egypt any monovoly or exclusive
right to act as advertising Agents
on its behalf. Advertisements of
every description are received at
the offices of the “Gazette” from
advertisers direct.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
